definitions.definition: a town or city with a harbour, especially one where ships load and unload goods
a place where ships load and unload goods or shelter from storms

examples.text: The ship spent four days in port.
**port of entry** *(= a place where people or goods can enter a country)*
She tried to steer the boat into port.
There was a spontaneous welcome for anyone who put into port on the island.

definitions.definition: a strong sweet wine, usually dark red, that is made in Portugal. It is usually drunk at the end of a meal.
the side of a ship or aircraft that is on the left when you are facing forward
a place on a computer where you can attach another piece of equipment, often using a cable
if you are in great trouble, you take any help that is offered

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 2 Old English, from Latin portus ‘haven, harbour’, reinforced in Middle English by Old French. noun senses 3 to 4 shortened form of Oporto, a major port in Portugal from which the wine is shipped. noun sense 5 mid 16th cent.: probably originally the side containing an entry port or facing the port (quayside) for loading. noun sense 6 Old English (in the sense ‘gateway’), from Latin porta ‘gate’; reinforced in Middle English by Old French porte. The later sense ‘opening in the side of a ship’ led to the general sense ‘opening’.
